reading_mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, plus メモ.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The first two kanji (土俵) use the on'yomi reading you learned. The last kanji 際 uses the kun'yomi reading, which you should know via the vocabulary. Just think of these two parts as somewhat separate bits of the word, which is why one part is on'yomi and another (the addition) is kun'yomi.

You have <reading>two chee</reading>se <reading>ca</reading>rs (つちか) that are growing mold. But that's a good thing, because it's the good kind of cheese mold. So, you cultivate the mold on these two cheese cars, comparing the difference between the two.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Let's put a <reading>new</reading> (ぬ) layer of paint on the wall. Then we'll plaster it.

If something is exhausted it's because you used up <reading>too</reading> (つ) much of it, and now it's all gone.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the two words this word is made up of, 帝国 and 主義.
You go <vocabulary>to color something</vocabulary>, painting the coloring all over the wall. Problem is, the coloring is made of ACID. This causes the wall to <reading>erode</reading> (いろど).
The reading comes from 後ろ and 盾 put together. Watch out for the rendaku.

The reading from 恥 is the ち reading, a reading you haven't learned yet. To remember this, just think about how the <reading>chee</reading>se <reading>jock</reading> is the biggest disgrace to this sports team. He is cheese, after all. He falls apart and smells funny.
It's <vocabulary>regrettable</vocabulary> if you're not <reading>coo</reading>l, <reading>yah</reading> (くや)? Yah, that would be pretty <vocabulary>vexing</vocabulary>.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The readings are the readings you learned with the kanji.

A <vocabulary>diagonal</vocabulary> is anything that's not a right angle. Even if something is at a 七 (なな) percent angle is a diagonal, <vocabulary>slanting</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>tilted</vocabulary> angle.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the kun'yomi reading of both kanji. The reading from 暗い and the reading of the kanji 闇.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
Someone is <reading>nag</reading>ging (なぐ) you and nagging you about something. You can't take it any more, so you turn around <vocabulary>to punch</vocabulary> them in the face.
The reading is the on'yomi readings of the kanji.

The thing that you melted in this situation is your <reading>toe</reading> (と). Feel your toe getting melted away. Augghh it hurts.

This word uses the on'yomi reading for the kanji, but you haven't learned the on'yomi reading for 岩, which is がん. When you think of <vocabulary>lava</vocabulary>, think about <reading>Ga</reading>ndhi, coming out of the lava. He's immune, because he's a robot.
The reading is the vocab reading for 火 and the reading you learned for 鉢, rendaku'd.

The reading is like that of 明るい, which means "bright." At least the あか part is the same. What is a <vocabulary>lamp</vocabulary> if not <reading>明</reading>るい (あか)? Another way to think of it is "what is a bright color?" The color <reading>赤</reading> (あか) is a bright color and would make a sexy lamp.
When you cook something, it's like you're a<reading>ttack</reading>ing (たく) the food with boiling water or fire or whatever. Attack the food by cooking it!
The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

The reading is 盆 plus 躍り put together into one word.
Think of a big ol' <vocabulary>shield</vocabulary>. It's so big it will stand (<reading>立て</reading>) tall right in front of you.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
You want <vocabulary>to smash</vocabulary> my stuff? That's <reading>coo' だ</reading> (くだ). Whatever you wanna do.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. This uses a different reading than the one you've already learned, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

Somebody was trying to <reading>mug</reading> (まぐ) you, but you managed to escape by pure <vocabulary>chance</vocabulary>! Your escape might have just been a <vocabulary>fluke</vocabulary>, but at least you didn't get mugged!
What is it that you have <vocabulary>to endure</vocabulary>? A barrage of <reading>ta</reading>cos (た), coming at you.

The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Now isn't that a bit <reading>wacky</reading> (わき)?
The reading is 脇's reading and 役's reading, put together.
The reading is the reading you learned with 脇 and the reading for 見る.
色 uses the しき reading (remember 景色?). Use that here with the 彩 kanji reading.

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You need <vocabulary>to amass</vocabulary> things, so you <reading>take one</reading> (たくわ) and put it aside, then take one more and put it aside again. Repeat this process of taking one over and over and you’ll quickly <vocabulary>store up</vocabulary> lots of things.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

The first kanji, 蚊, uses the reading you learned. The second kanji has an exceptional reading, や. To remember や, think about how you had to take a giant <vocabulary>mosquito net</vocabulary> and cover all of <reading>Ya</reading>nkee (や) Stadium. They have a rough mosquito problem.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

The reading for 車 is the vocab reading, くるま. Then, 椅子 is いす.

The <reading>cog yak</reading> is so shiny. It's so shiny that it starts <vocabulary>to shine</vocabulary> and glitter. I don't know what a cog yak is, but imagine it in your head and imagine it being super shiny, shining off shines and glitter.

The reading for 隙 is the one you learned with the kanji and the 間 is the 間に合う reading.

Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 零す.
